{{Infobox NFL season | team = Los Angeles Rams | teamcolor = Los Angeles Rams 73thru94 | year = 1985 | record = 11â5 | division_place = 1st [[NFC West]] | coach = [[John Robinson (American football coach)|John Robinson]] | stadium = [[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Anaheim Stadium]] |uniform = | playoffs = '''Won''' Divisional
Lost Conference }} [[Image:Rams 40th.png|thumb|40th Anniversary in Los Angeles]] The '''[[1985 NFL season|1985]] [[St. Louis Rams|Los Angeles Rams]] season''' was the team's 48th year with the [[National Football League]] and the 40th season in [[Los Angeles]]. The Rams played in the NFC Championship Game but lost to the eventual Super Bowl champion Chicago Bears. Eric Dickerson rushed for 1,234 yards in [[1985 NFL season|1985]] while missing the first two games while in a contract dispute. He missed the [[Pro Bowl]] for the first time in his short NFL career. He did, however, go on to rush for a playoff record 248 yards against the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in post-season play.Eric Dickerson: Pro Football Hall of Fame, http://www.profootballhof.com/hof/member.jsp?PLAYER_ID=55 {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Offseason==



===NFL Draft=== {|class="wikitable sortable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- !style="background:#A8BDEC;" width=7%|Round !!width=7% style="background:#A8BDEC;"|Pick #!!width=15% style="background:#A8BDEC;"|Player !!width=16% style="background:#A8BDEC;"|Position !!width=20% style="background:#A8BDEC;"|College |- |align=center| 1||21||bgcolor="#FFCC00"|[[Jerry Gray]]||Cornerback||[[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]] |- |align=center| 2||50||Chuck Scott||Wide Receiver||[[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]] |- |align=center| 3||77||Dale Hatcher||Punter||[[Clemson Tigers football|Clemson]] |- |align=center| 5||113||bgcolor="#FFCC00"|[[Kevin Greene]]||Linebacker||[[Auburn University|Auburn]] |- |align=center| 6||161||Mike Young||Wide Receiver||[[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] |- |}http://www.pro-football-reference.com/draft/1985.htm ==Regular season== The Los Angeles Rams got off to a surprisingly successful start in 1985, winning their first seven games. However, the team struggled somewhat during the second half of the season. After suffering humiliating losses to the 1-9 [[Atlanta Falcons]] and the 4-8 [[New Orleans Saints]], the Rams upset their main rival, the [[San Francisco 49ers]] on the road in a prime time Monday-Night match-up, despite being 10-point underdogs going into the game. This crucial victory helped the Rams redeem their season and the team went on to clinch their first NFC West division title in six years, finishing the regular season with an 11-5 record. ===Schedule=== {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- align="center" style="background:#14345B;color:#ffc322;" | '''Game''' || '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || '''Result''' || '''Rams points''' || '''Opponents''' || '''Record''' || '''Streak''' || '''Venue''' || '''Attendance |- align="center" bgcolor=#ddffdd | 1 || September 8, 1985 || [[Denver Broncos]] || W || 20 || 16 || 1-0 || W1 || [[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Anaheim Stadium]] ||

|- align="center" bgcolor=#ddffdd |Divisional Playoff || January 4, 1986 || [[Dallas Cowboys]] || W || 20 || 0 || 12-5 || W1 || [[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Anaheim Stadium]] || 66,351 |- align="center" bgcolor=#ffdddd |Conference Championship || January 12, 1986 || at [[Chicago Bears]] || L || 0 || 24 || 12-6 || L1 || [[Soldier Field]] || 65,522 |}http://www.jt-sw.com/football/pro/results.nsf/Teams/1985-lam ===Standings=== {{1985 NFC West standings}} ==Statistics== ===Passing=== {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- align="center" style="background:#14345B;color:#ffc322;" | '''Player''' || '''Games Played''' ||'''Completions''' || '''Attempts''' || '''Yards''' || '''Touchdowns''' || '''Interceptions''' || '''Rating''' |- | [[Dieter Brock]] || 15 || 218 || 365 || 2658 || 16 || 13 || 82.0 |- | [[Jeff Kemp]] || 5 ||16|| 38 || 214 || 0 || 1 || 49.7 |- |} http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/ram/1985.htm ===Rushing=== {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- align="center" style="background:#14345B;color:#ffc322;" | '''Player''' || '''Games Played''' || '''Attempts''' || '''Yards''' || '''Touchdowns''' || '''Longest run''' |- | Eric Dickerson|| 14 || 292 || 1234 || 12 || 43 |- | Barry Redden|| 14 || 87 || 380 || 0 || 41 |- | Charles White || 16 || 70 || 310 || 3 ||32 |- | Dieter Brock|| 15 || 20 || 38 ||0 ||13 |- | Lynn Cain || 7|| 11 || 46 || 0 ||9 |- | Mike Guman || 8|| 11 || 32 || 0 ||6 |- | Jeff Kemp|| 5 || 5 || 0 || 0 ||3 |- | Henry Ellard || 16 || 3 || 8 ||0 ||16 |- | Ron J. Brown || 13 || 2 || 13 || 0 || 9 |- | Steve Dils || 15 || 2 || -4 || 0 || -2 |- |} ===Receiving=== {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- align="center" style="background:#14345B;color:#ffc322;" | '''Player''' || '''Receptions''' || '''Yards''' || '''Touchdowns''' || '''Longest reception''' |- | Henry Ellard|| 54 || 811 || 5 || 64 |- | Tony Hunter|| 50 || 562 || 4 || 47 |- | David Hill|| 29 || 271 || 1 ||37 |- | Bobby Duckworth|| 25 || 422 || 3 || 42 |- |} ==Playoffs== ===NFC Divisional Playoff=== {{Americanfootballbox | title=Los Angeles Rams 20, Dallas Cowboys 0 |titlestyle=text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Los Angeles Rams 73thru94}} |Road=Cowboys |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=0 |Home='''Rams''' |H1=3 |H2=0 |H3=10 |H4=7 |HT=20 |stadium= [[Anaheim Stadium]], [[Anaheim, California]] |date= [[January 4, 1986]] |time= 4:00 p.m. [[North American Eastern Standard Time Zone|EST]]/1:00 p.m. [[Pacific Standard Time Zone|PST]] |weather= {{convert|67|Â°F|Â°C}}, fog, drizzle |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jack Buck]], [[Hank Stram]], and [[Dick Vermeil]] |referee= [[Dick Jorgensen]] }} Running back [[Eric Dickerson]] led the Rams to a victory by scoring two touchdowns and recording a playoff record 248 rushing yards. After the first half ended with a 3-0 Los Angeles lead, Dickerson scored on a 55-yard touchdown run early in the third period. On the ensuing kickoff, Kenny Duckett fumbled, and the ball was recovered by [[Vince Newsome]] to set up kicker [[Mike Lansford]]'s second field goal. In the fourth period, [[Tony Hunter (American football)|Tony Hunter]] recovered a fumbled punt to set up Dickerson's 40-yard rushing touchdown. The Rams' defense dominated the Cowboys' offense all afternoon as the Cowboys never got inside the Rams' 20-yard-line. ===NFC Championship Game=== {{Americanfootballbox | title=Chicago Bears 24, Los Angeles Rams 0 |titlestyle=text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Los Angeles Rams 73thru94}} |Road=Rams |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=0 |Home='''Bears''' |H1=10 |H2=0 |H3=7 |H4=7 |HT=24 |stadium= [[Soldier Field]], [[Chicago]] |date= [[January 12, 1986]] |time= 12:30 p.m. [[North American Eastern Standard Time Zone|EST]]/11:30 a.m. [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= {{convert|37|Â°F|Â°C}}, cloudy, snow showers |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Pat Summerall]] and [[John Madden (football)|John Madden]] |referee= [[Jim Tunney (American football official)|Jim Tunney]] }} The Bears defense dominated the game by limiting Rams running back [[Eric Dickerson]] to 46 yards rushing, and holding quarterback [[Dieter Brock]] to just 10 completions out of 31 pass attempts for 66 passing yards. Los Angeles only gained 130 yards of total offense. The Rams had a chance to get back in the game as they got inside the Bears' 15 yard line in the waning moments of the first half, but poor play calling and clock management, as well as a controversial call by the officials on the last play of the half, resulted in the clock running out. Officials' ability to review plays (via instant replay) was not made available until the following season. ==Awards and records== ===Milestones=== Gary Jeter, NFL Comeback Player of Year. ==See also== ;Other Anaheimâbased teams in 1985 * '''[[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California Angels]]''' ''([[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Anaheim Stadium]])'' ** [[1985 California Angels season]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/ram/1985.htm 1985 Los Angeles Rams Season at Pro-Football Reference] {{Los Angeles Rams}} {{1985 NFL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1985 Los Angeles Rams Season}} [[Category:1985 National Football League season by team|Los Angeles Rams]] [[Category:Los Angeles Rams seasons]] [[Category:NFC West championship seasons]]
